Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The provenance of "Grenville" age detrital zircon in western North America and the Neoproterozoic to early Paleozoic evolution of southwestern Laurentia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: The provenance of "Grenville" age detrital zircon in western North America and the Neoproterozoic to early Paleozoic evolution of southwestern Laurentia

R. Lang Farmer, University of Colorado, EAR-1251851
Christopher Fedo, University of Tennessee, EAR-1251869

ABSTRACT
Detrital zircon U-Pb age determinations have become a primary tool in siliciclastic sedimentary provenance studies due in part to the advent of rapid, in situ methods of obtaining isotopic data from individual zircon grains. However, the ability to collect such data is outstripping our understanding of the limitations of using U-Pb age spectra in interpreting continental tectonics and paleogeography. In this study, PIs are interested in assessing the significance, in terms of the sediment provenance, of variations in the age spread and relative peak height of specific detrital zircon age populations in siliciclastic sedimentary successions. Their approach is through combined in situ zircon U-Pb and Hf isotope analyses, data to be obtained using the laser ablation-multicollector ICPMS technique. PIs will target Mesoproterozoic to Cambrian sedimentary successions in the SW United States and northern Mexico, rocks that have been extensively used for U-Pb detrital zircon studies, but for which there is little detrital zircon Hf isotope data. Existing U-Pb age spectra reveal that a significant fraction of the detrital zircons in these rocks were derived from 1.0 Ga to 1.3 Ga ("Grenville") basement sources. The width and relative peak heights described by detrital zircon in this age range vary considerably both temporally and spatially within these sedimentary successions. Many samples are dominated by ~1.1 Ga detrital zircon, which on the basis of their U-Pb ages alone implies that these zircon were all derived from the same Mesoproterozoic basement source. However, PIs pilot Hf isotopic studies of "Grenville" detrital zircon show that the ~1.1 Ga grains vary by over 15 epsilonHf(0) units and reveal that these zircons do not all share the same provenance. This fact is not recognizable from the U-Pb age spectra alone. Based on this observation, it is suggested that combined U-Pb and Hf isotopic data can be used to explore how changes in the characteristics of the "Grenville" peaks in detrital zircon age spectra reflect changes in the ultimate bedrock source of these detrital grains. A better understanding of the basement provenance for Mesoproterozoic detrital zircons can, in turn, be used terms to refine models for the Precambrian to early Paleozoic tectonic and paleogeographic evolution of North America. PIs will conduct a broad survey of the U-Pb and Hf isotopic compositions of potential sources of "Grenville" zircon amongst 1.0 Ga to 1.3 Ga igneous rocks within the Grenville Orogen in the central and southern Appalachians, in the Llano Uplift in Texas, and among the ~1.1 Ga igneous rocks distributed throughout Paleoproterozoic crust of the SW U.S. and northern Mexico. They will apply this information, along with whole-rock Nd isotopic analyses on samples for which such data not already available, to assess the provenance of "Grenville" detrital zircon in siliciclastic sedimentary rocks in the Death Valley region and in the Caborca area of central Sonora (MX).

An important aspect of understanding how the geography of the surface of the planet evolves is determining where sediments found in rivers, deltas, beaches, and in the ocean come from. Over time, we know that there have been substantial changes in the kinds of environments and their locations on the North American continent as a result of mountain building and changes in climate.  In the modern world, scientists can determine where sediment (mineral grains of sand) comes from by following rivers back to their source lands or studying the currents in the ocean. For sedimentary rocks that were deposited millions of years ago, that kind of approach cannot be used because source areas where sediment comes from may have been completely eroded, and rocks are not sufficiently exposed to track track the transport direction in the level of detail  modern river systems. However, even in modern river (or beach, or marine) sand, not every grain of sand contains information that permits it to be identified with a specific source from where it came. Some minerals, specifically zircon, have the element uranium (U) in it that turns into the elment lead (Pb) at a known rate so the age of it can be determined. Because zircon is common in sand and in most mountains where sand comes from, it can be possible to determine where it came from by knowing the age of the source zircon and the age of the sand zircons.

In one recent study of modern river sand, researchers collected different samples of sand from a single dune in the channel. Becuase water flows in the river at different speeds, the grains of sand can be separated on how much each weighs, with bigger grains weighing more, and smaller grains weighing less. The samples collected from the river all had different grain sizes. Sand grains of zircon were found in the samples and their ages were determined and showed that depending on the size of these grains the resulting ages changed. However becuase these grains were collected from all near each other, they should have come from the same places, and thus have all the same ages. That they do not means that the source area has rocks of different ages and the zircons in each source have distinctive sizes.

This type of study had not been done in ancient river sediments that now are preserved as rocks. In the study we did, we identified two distinct ancient river channels in California (the sediment in the channels was deposited about 550 million years ago) and collected samples all near each other, but from different sizes of sand, to test the hypothesis that the samples, like in the modern river, would all have zircons with a different group of ages. Our results in both of the studied ancient channels differed from the study in the modern river: regardless of the grain size of the sand the ages of the zircons all matched each other, and would lead to the conclusion that each sample was derived from the same source area as would be expected intuitively. We further failed to find any correlation between the ages of the zircons and their shapes,  as well as ages and how smooth their surfaces are. As a result, we are confident that we could identify the potential source of these ancient sedimentary rocks.

Another element found in the mineral zircon is hafnium (Hf). Like with the age, this element is linked to the source and combined provides a powerful tool to track where sediment could have come from. In our analyses of samples in this study that combine age and hafnium, we determined the best location in North America where the sand could have come from is within the present day position of Texas. We can now build a picture of what part of North America looked like about 550 million years ago.
